Title: Mouse, Mousie
Source: Choksy, L. (1981). The Kodaly Context. Upper Saddle River, NJ: Prentice Hall
Classroom Use: Introduce do, Practice ti-ti, Game
Game:
Students form a seated circle. 
A "Mousie" is selected by the teacher and stands and closes their eyes. A "Kitty" is secretly selected by the teacher (optionally with all students' eyes closed). Mousie walks around the outside of the circle while students sing. On 'you', Kitty jumps up and runs around the circle to chase Mousie. Mousie can win by sitting in Kitty's spot. Win or lose, the Kitty becomes the new Mousie and a new Kitty is secretly chosen by the teacher.
Full Rhythm: t tt tt tt t t tt t tt tt tt tt t t tt t

Title: Pease Porridge Hot
Source: Forrai, K. (1995). Music in Preschool. New York, NY. Boosey & Hawkes.
Classroom Use: Introduce do, Practice rest
Game:

Title: Paw Paw Patch
Source: Rohrbough, L. (1940). Hand Play Party Book. Delaware, OH. Cooperative Recreation Service.
Classroom Use: Introduce tika-tika, Practice re, Practice s,, Practice t,
Game:
Students form two lines (Line 1 & Line 2), all facing forward.
Verse 1 = Student 1 in Line 2 walks clockwise around Line 2 and Line 1 and back to original spot.
Verse 2 = Same student walks around again, this time with all of the students in Line 1 following behind.

The rest of the students go under the arch and go around each line again and back up to where they started. The first student in each line goes to the bottom of the lines and there is a new student in the front of each line.

Title: Rocky Road
Source: Bennett, L. (1957). Children's Jamaican Songs and Games. Sound Recording, FW 7250. Transcribed C. Roberts June, 2014.
Type: Call and Response, Play Party, Gate Game
Classroom Use: Call and Response, Play Party, Syncopation
Game:
Students form two lines facing each other with raised hands to form an arch.
The couple at one end drops hands and trots through the arch to the other and form an arch when theу get there. The other couples follow in succession, the lines moving towards the original starting point of the game. That means that the lines are always moving until the point. The first couple gets back to its original starting point. The first couple now drops hands and trots, each on the again outside of his line, towards the end, where they face each other and form an arch. The other couples do the same thing until the first couple is again in its original position, when the game ends.

Classroom Use: Play Party, Practice re, Practice syn-co-pa, Introduce syn-co-pa, Practice s,
Game:
Students form two lines facing each other, about six feet apart.

Title: Frog in the Meadow
Source: Schinhan, J. (1962). Frank C. Brown Collection of North Carolina Folklore, Vol.V. Durham, NC. Duke University Press
Classroom Use: Introduce re, Practice do, Introduce rest, Practice rest
Game:
Students form a seated circle. A “Frog” is chosen to stand in the center.
During the song, the Frog rotates in place pointing outward towards the students. At the end, the Frog stops spinning and their finger stops and points at two students. The two students stand and the Frog stands between them. On ‘go’, the students race outside the circle in opposite directions away from the Frog. The first student around the circle to make it back to the Frog is the winner and becomes the new Frog. Note: when the runners are going around the circle, they must pass each other. Encourage them to high-five each other to avoid a froggy collision.

Title: Zapatitos Blancos
Source: Montoya-Stier, G. (2008). El Patio de mi Casa: 42 traditional rhymes, chants, and folk songs from Mexico. Chicago, IL. GIA. p. 20
Classroom Use: Practice rest, Language: Spanish
Game:
Students form a seated circle with both legs extended in front of them. The teacher or a student leader is chosen to be inside the circle.
The leader pats a steady beat around the circle, tapping each student’s shoe as everyone speaks the rhyme. On the last beat of the rhyme, the student on whom the beat lands says how old they are. The beat continues around the circle for however old the student is. (For example, if the student is seven, the beat passes seven more shoes.) 
When the beat lands on the final shoe, that person’s foot is eliminated from the game. They tuck it underneath them, out of the circle, so one foot is still in the game and one foot is out. Continue until all shoes are eliminated.

At the words, “What time, Old Witch?” the Witch rushes from her hideout, seizes a Chicken, takes it to her hiding place, and calls out “One.”
The Chickens again form a line behind Craney Crow and the game is resumed from the beginning. As the Witch seizes the second Chicken, she answers to the question, “What time, Old Witch?” the word “Two,” and soon “Three, Four, etc.,” until twelve Chickens have been seized. In case the number of players is small, the Witch seizes half of Craney Crow’s Chickens.
After this has been done, the singing stops; the Witch draws a line on the ground with a stick, and the Chickens behind the Witch and the Chickens behind Craney Crow pull against each other. The first child pulled across the line on the Witch’s side becomes the new Witch; the first child pulled across the line on Craney Crow’s side becomes the new Craney Crow, and the game is begun again from the very beginning.
source: kodalycollection.org, Altona Trent-Jones, Play Songs of the Deep South, 1944.

Title: Sarasponda
Source: Beall, P. & Nipp S. (1982). Wee Sing Around the Campfire. Los Angeles, CA. Price Stern Sloan
Classroom Use: Practice tam-ti, Introduce do'
Game:
Students pair up and sit across from each other, each holding a rhythm stick in each hand. They are assigned A and B
Bt. 1 - Students tap the sticks on the ground beside them
Bt. 2 - Students clap their own sticks
Bt. 3 - Students click their R stick with each other
Bt. 4 - Students clap their own sticks
Bt. 5 - Students click their L stick with each other
Bts. 6-7 - A holds their sticks up shoulder length apart, B readies their sticks in between. They click their sticks 3 times to ‘ret-set-set’, A moving in-out-in and B moving out-in-out, moving their sticks past each other with each click.
Bt. 8 - Rest, students raise their sticks high to prepare to tap the ground
Bts. 9-16 - Repeat beats 1-8
Bt. 17 - Students toss R stick in the air making one full rotation on ‘do’.
Bt. 19.5 - Students clap own sticks together as two 8th notes in the space of the rest
Bt. 20 - Students toss L stick in the air making one full rotation on ‘do’.
Bt. 22.5 - Students clap own sticks together as two 8th notes in the space of the rest
Bt. 25 - Students tap the sticks on the ground beside them
Bt. 26 - Students clap their own sticks
Bt. 27-28 - Repeat beats 6-7, in-out-in/out-in-out movement
Bt. 29 - Students tap the sticks on the ground beside them
Bt. 30 - Students clap their own sticks
Bt. 31 - Students clap their partner sticks
Increase the difficulty: For beats 17 and 20 instead of tossing and catching their own stick, the students can toss them to each other and catch them

Title: Weevily Wheat

Classroom Use: Practice syn-co-pa, Practice tika-ti, Practice so, Classroom: Math
Game:
Students form standing circle groups of 4. Before starting, each student gets a number 1,2,3 or 4.

M. 8 – On each beat, each student stacks their left hand on top, pulling their hand from the bottom of the pile. (1,2,3,4)

Title: Over the River Charlie
Source: Library of Congress AFS 01732 A4 Collected by Alan and Elizabeth Lomax. Variation from Beth's Notes.
Classroom Use: Practice ti-tika, Practice tika-ti, Practice te,, Learn mixolydian
Game:
Students form two long lines facing each other. The two students at the end of each line are the head couple.
Refrain:
Ms. 1-4 = Head couple sashay down between the two lines.
Ms. 5-8 = Head couple sashay up to where they started.
Verse 1:
Ms. 9-12 = Head couple right arm swing 1.5 times around
Ms. 13-16 = Head couple left arm swing one student from the opposite line.
Refrain: Repeat Ms. 9-16 with next students in the lines.
The head couple continues in the same way until all students have had a turn to swing the head couple. Then, the Head couple stands at the end of each line and a new head couple begins the sequence.
